segments.text: John Lawrence.
I'm planning an exhibition called By the Hand of a Woman.
It thrives in illuminations and the provenance are manuscripts delicious by women for women.
Clear provenance, no leaving.
This came out as a result of a lecture at Indiana.
And I had a group of very scholarly library science people that probably earned their masters in the 70s.
Very prim, proper, the old guard library people.
I mean, very civilized, intellectual, lovely movie.
Pardon me?
I wrote their names down, and I'm giving this call.
Yeah, that time.
And I mentioned, I held up this manuscript, it's a Carmelite manuscript, and I made an off remark.
Now these are very prim and proper, ladies, okay?
I'm very chink to you.
And say, I think it would be really nice if someone would do an exhibition of works by women for women.
And they turned in, as Rush Limbaugh would call Feminots, and said, where's it at?
I go, whoa, get an idea.
So they jumped me after the lecture and said, are you going to do that?
Are you going to do that?
I said, I don't know if I can do it.
I said, works by women are very rare in this period.
The best I will do, if you will take charge of logistics, and as this is the planning stage, I said, I will see what I can do.
So I went to all the top book dealers in the world, and I said, I'd like works by women.
And they go, why?
OK, I'm going to do an exhibition by women.
I go, why?
So I hold up the almighty dollar a pound, as it may be.
Now, that shark smells of blood.
But then they start, look, they have nothing.
So I have them scouring around.
And I find pieces and institutional questions.
I go home and do an inventory what I have.
Bucks it off.
One guy comes back and says, as far as I know, you have the largest collection of what's by women in a private collection.
Certainly east of the Mississippi.
And I said, pardon me, did you say works?
Are you talking about manuscripts?
I'm talking about illuminations and manuscripts, scribings.
But are these strictly by women?
These are very rarely signed.
Well, you get that by, this is where the book breaking comes in, where they have the original book, which is clearly identified as to monastery.
In the case of the antiphonal of Marguerite de Bocqueville, she signed it.
Three times she signed it in an initial.
I mean, it was a very arrogant act for a Renaissance woman to do, and I'm being facetious here.
So I'd been involved with Marguerite Bacovall's Antipano when it was intact.
It was purchased at Christie's, I think, for $25,000.
I'm not clear on that.
And I was there with a book breaker who showed it to me.
And that was magnificent, the whole book.
And it was a magnificent book.
And I said, you can't, Tim.
I said, how much do you want for the book?
Unbroken.
He said, pay $25,000 for it.
I want $45,000 for it.
I said, OK.
I go home.
My wife, here we go with the home equity loan.
Get $45,000 certified check.
Turn around.
Right back to his full gallery, 45,000, where's the book?
He said, you're not going to get it.
He said, I want 100,000 for now.
I said, what are you going to do with it?
I knew he was going to do it.
He's going to break it.
He opens up, there's seven miniatures in it.
He said, these miniatures will retail as a minimum.
8,000, 9,000 articles.
Is he an American bookseller?
Yeah, American bookseller.
Do we know who it is?
Oh, I know who it is.
I'll talk to you about that privately.
I mean, do I know who it is?
Yeah, you know his name when I drop it.
We all know.
Yeah, it's kind of a nefarious name.
And I think quite a lot of you all know that the business is doing this.
Yeah, well, not publicly.
I mean, when you put a mouse in a box with a hungry cat, what do you think is going to happen?
He then says, look at these initials.
Marguerite de Bocavel had hired Louis Bacard, a Renaissance artist, to do the miniatures.
She directed the themes, and she directed the initials.
Then she did over 300 sketches, illuminations herself of various themes, including what looks like a portrait of her sister, Patton Hoban.
She had the audacity to sign the book,
She was a Carthusian nut, and this is completely opposite.
So I told him, I said, you can't break this book.
He said, this book is worth a million dollars, book.
He said, you know how this works.
And I said, that's the problem.
I said, I'm warning you, don't do this.
He went from $45,000 to a million, right?
Pardon me?
He went from $45,000 to a million in a matter of hours, basically.
He thought.
He thought he did.
Yeah, and that's the way this works.
So this is the same guy who wanted to break a Tyndale Bible, by the way.
Is this Graham we're talking about?
Pardon me?
Is this Graham the Raider?
No.
No.
No.
He's got his own little area.
So we know who we're not talking about.
So I said to him, I want to buy as many of the miniatures as I can.
Well, he wants the national deficits.
And he doesn't want to give them to me because he knows that I'm going to use them.
They're not going to disappear to some obscure private collection.
So he sells them off to other manuscript dealers.
So he did great for that.
Oh, broke it apart.
Cut it apart.
That's horrible.
Well, these guys are always desperate for cash in one way or another.
They'll make a fortune on one book and go out and do something stupid or another.
Times get hard.
I go to one of the manuscript dealers who has the main miniature.
It's a white woman of Jerusalem.
Very feministy, disguised as the ascension.
It is even the text.
Rise up, ye daughters of Jerusalem.
Very feministy.
So times are hard.
I get this miniature for like $6,000, which is really a bargain.
He lets go of a number of the smaller miniatures, or the smaller leaves.
I'd already collected as many of her individual leaves as I could find.
They were selling, plain leaves were selling for $400 a cup.
Ones with initials, beautiful initials, were $600.
Multiple initials, $1,200.
You can do the math.
You know, you have 100-some leaves, you know, this number.
So I find the other book dealer has two of her signatures.
He needs money quick, so he sells them to me for like 900 hours each.
Is this the same guy?
No, different guy.
The book breaker has subcontracted his whole sale piece out to people.
So I buy both of those.
Then he finds out I'm really interested in this, and he says, by the way, I've got one that's dated.

in the initial 1539 how much do you want because i want 900 i said okay that's fine i buy it for you five friends and by the way i get five of your carmelite leaves on a assignment as i threw those in with the deal i think this is what you deal with these guys i mean you know it's like sharks nipping at each other if you don't nip back they're not going to respect you so
I have to keep this business of this women's exhibition quiet because I know what it's going to do.
It's going to force the price at least through the roof.
So I go out and acquire all the Carmelite, which was a large antiphonal, the Carmelite Order.
It was scribed on paper, beautiful hand-leaf paper, illuminated.
One of the illuminations looks like a quilt.
And in the middle of the book,
which is very rare, are two large leaves and a very good yet very derivative form of lack of instructions by a woman to a woman on how to notate and rubricate music.
First of all, it's in the middle of a book, which is rare for that to happen, accepted by the women.
I said, what do you want for those?
And he says, 150 each.
I said, I've got to be honest with you.
Do you know what those are?
No, they're from the Carmelite.
This one guy can read a little bit of Latin.
Most of them can't read any Latin.
I said, do you know what the temple is?
You know what it says?
He said, no, I don't know the first word, which is a derivative to give advice.
I said, it's instructions.
I said, I'll buy both of them.
I'll buy every piece of Carmelite you have, because that book was intact.
So what we're doing in the exhibition is only including leaves and have a 100% clear provenance.
And Jim Merrill from Princeton authenticated a miniature I had, which was done by the four players.
Very beautiful miniature.
Next thing I know,
I hear from the McMaster University people in Hamilton, and they're doing, they have a website of Medieval Women.
They have a television series.
I said, do you want to collaborate with us?
Well, what do we need to do?
I said, I want you to do, this is going to be an educational exhibition.
I want you to do the brochures.
I want you to do the extraneous material.
It's not just an art exhibition.
It's a writing, painting, history of the women, motivation of women exhibition.
She said...
We negotiate.
Let me ask you, do you know the name Jeffrey Hamburger, who's now at Harvard, and kind of specializes in women with medieval manuscripts?
I've never met him.
I know the name.
He used to teach at Obama.
He was in Eric's position.
If you could connect me.
I've heard the name.
I could do that.
I'm sure Eric Engels teaches Medieval in our Art History department on Jeffrey Hamburger.
As I understand it from Eric, this was really his specialty, because I mentioned to Eric
that you were working on this medieval manuscript by women.
And then he said, oh, that's Jeffrey's thing.
Well, what he could do is help me locate pieces in collections that people may want to loan out.
There's the, well, the book you're going to have, The Dominican Reverie, that was all done by women, five different women, from cover to cover.
And that was very close to being broken.
I think I told you that before I inquired that.
I'm the same guy.
Where is the exhibition going to be?
What's going to open at the Shelley Museum in Harmony, Indiana, it's going to go to McMaster in Canada, and then after that, I'm keeping it open to find out what Oberlin wants to do.
It's not going to go to Northern Ohio.
It's going to go to the East Coast.
And I'm falling out of it.
I'm letting the women scholars take over.
They are really great.
They're rabid.
They really love this.
They're on a mission.
And I'm completely off of it.
I'm putting the pieces together.
I'm doing the legwork with the book dealers.
and letting them do the scholarship.
You know, it's not going to be the most impressive thing, you see, but it's very unusual now.
Well, it's a start.
I talked to Sandra Hindman, who is one of the top five now.
I said, Sandra, and she's the chair of the Art History Department of Northwestern.
She's also a manuscript.
I said, do you have any work by women?
She said, no.
Seconds of 19th century illuminations by women.
So why not?
So we're going from New Harmony, Indiana.
I'd say we're going to be here a while.
In New Harmony, Indiana, they're going to bring in Jane Owen, Jane Owen,
very rare
Early American fracture done by the harmonists.
Jane Owen, who was behind us in New Harmony, never approached her.
New Harmony was the place I went for years.
I always wanted to meet her, and one of the scholars approached her, and she's really great on that.
She said, well, I'm going to contact the historic New Harmony, and contact the people at the Pennsylvania.
And so we do loan us your fracture, which is quite, you know, no one just does that.
So we'll loan it for this exhibition.
And whether they allow it to follow the exhibitions in their story, but they sent it to, they said, yeah, it'll be there in New Harmony.
And so we're putting together something that's 14th, 15th, 16th, 17th, 18th, 19th century.
And then I'm going to have one of the people look at some 20th century Illuminates that are women.
So the whole idea is to put together, but where I'm coming around the circle to tell Nick is, I'm going to tell the story.
They want to know about the Backevel thing, which has been tremendously painful to me, about who broke this book.
I mean, no one's ever asked me, Nick, no one ever asked me, who writes these books?
I mean, I give lectures, I'm getting this lately.
Who wrote this book?
Your old book.
I can't mention its name, but you can until my attorney clears it.
You know it.
You've attended anything?
Yeah, yeah.
Who lives in this area?
He lives in Northern, Ohio.
In the Akron area?
Mm-hmm.
He's a bookseller.
His first name wouldn't be Bruce, would it?
Nancy James.
Oh, thank God.
That's amazing.
Are you talking about Bruce Berrini?
Did I say that name?
You'll find a lot of information real quick.
I thought you had a closer association.
You have no close association with these people.
You have no close association with these people.
You have a symbionic relationship with all of these people, as Nick will tell you.
If you want access to the material,

you have to be very pragmatic and therefore you know these people could shut me down in a moment i mean it's a closed group and it comes to medieval books renaissance books of five people in the world and they're all interconnected and at a moment they can shut shut me down i mean they could they could do it in a moment and i don't think it'll happen
Because I'm doing a lot of exhibitions and lectures.
I would shut you down in what respect?
Well, if they decided I was a threat to their business, they would shut me down.
If you chose book breaking, if you kind of attack them on the issue of book breaking... Well, I've already gotten one phone call after I did a speech in Philadelphia.
You know what you need, Don?
You need somebody who is not dependent on you.
Well, you know, that's the problem.
Well, I do it, you know.
I name names.
Well, I understand that.
I understand you do, but we'll have to talk about that, and we'll have to back it up.
You have to be very careful about what you're saying.
I have to be very careful, but accept the fact that I've been around this so long, I don't even know where they're footnotes in journals.
I understand that I'm very careful with what I do, too.
I'm the guy who writes the books, and if there are any lawsuits, they're into me.
Minor old guard manuscript dealers who absolutely hate some of the big names.
You have two groups in it.
You have this group that's extremely ethical, which has died out.
The whole dog?
And actually, their prices on the leaves are realistic.
And then you have the group that came in in the 80s and the 90s that built their business.
The top five now are Farini.
Well, I would say the top five are Farini,
Sam Fogg in London.
Sam Fogg?
Sam Fogg.
F-O-G-G.
That's where this shipment was coming from today.
Now, we're not talking about breakers.
We're talking about dealers.
But, you know, the question you always have to ask, Nick, is where's the line between and how did they get there?
You're talking Jorn Gunther in Germany.
Yes, yes, I have.
He has to be one of the leading guys, wouldn't you think?
I write about him in this new book.
I don't know how leading he is.
His name has never hit my radar.
Read the chapter.
I mean, I write about him in the new book.
I will, but his name has never hit.
He really doesn't sell that much in the States.
That's why he doesn't.
He says he has 35 customers in the world.
Well, then that's probably why I've heard him.
This was who again?
Tenture.
Yeah, but I've heard the name.
Yeah, who started out in Bavaria, and he's now in Switzerland.
What I'll do is I'll take a look at that.
Run his name.
He's got a website.
Take a look at his website.
Read what I have to write about him in the book.
John, it sounded like from the description of that that he was selling complete medieval manuscript.
He was not breaking that at all.
Totally high-end.
Absolutely.
He looks for things that are really special.
And as Dick was describing it, he kind of falls in love with these things.
And then he goes out to his small group of people and convinces them to fall in love with it.
And then they'll pay the big money.
So he's a salesperson.
Extraordinary.
Catalog.
Catalog.
He's got a website.
Go take a look at his website.
Just do a search, Google search.

or if he refused to sell for them two of which people two of the two of the big five i started to name oh just drop his name and see did you ever get anything from him i don't think he sells it i don't think he has this yeah well i want to find out

And that's what he does.

What does Conrad Black know about him?
Nothing.
No, he doesn't like the appearances.
Yeah, but I mean, the guy's got the money.
What do any of these guys know about a precious art in the 80s and early 90s?
I mean,
Here's my $40 million impression of art.
Here's my $40 million Monet.
Isn't it beautiful?
Here's my $40 million Monet.
That's what's happening with medieval books.
Here's my 14th century... I'm writing about this in that chapter I was talking about in this book.
John Wendell says... Is this your new book?
Yeah, the big book.
The little one.
The little one.
I don't know if I really...
I don't care who they are.
And I don't want the Christie's to suffer these.
Because frankly, you know, they're just options.
I mean, that's where the book breakers go.
Talk a bit about the book breakers.
I mean, is this something that's new?
It's not new.
It goes back to the 20th century.
I didn't think we were doing it anymore, so we're doing it again.
That's what's been unique about it.
I mean, doing it, it was feeding time in the 80s and 90s.
I mean, books of ours, Boston University had a big sale.
I gave a talk which was very controversial on what I called institutionalized co-conspirators and book breakers.
And I really stepped on a nerve
And I had my facts straight, so they were in a hard position.
I traced several books, including the Hildensei book, which you've seen.
And I got all the data on it.
And all the ex officio collection went through the institution to talk.
Boston University did, in the late 80s, a massive sale from their Institute for Bibles.
Now, this isn't Howard Gottlieb who's doing this.
He's the one that's head of the special collections.
No.
Oh, no.
No, there was an Institute.
for biblical research or something.
Biblical?
Yeah.
And I'll have to get you the details.
I know it's a quick story.
I mean the exact title.
And they had a catalog.
I don't go with anything without the documentation.
Well, no, no, but I would.
I'm just giving you a new story.
And they had a massive catalog of books of ours, religious books they sold.
And the book breakers were there.
And they got involved in this.
And they bought these books.
And I don't know how many of these books of ours that they have.
Yeah.
Boston University did in their seat.
Well, here's what happened in the lecture.
One guy challenged me.
And he said, I want to go on record in saying that every of the institutions here, we hope that it is our time.
But I said, cut the crap.
You know who buys these books.
If you put a fat, hungry mouse...
a bat mouse in a box with a hungry cat.
What do you think is going to happen?
I said, you have a fiduciary responsibility to understand who gets this.
I said, you have a moral responsibility because I sat there and watched these books of ours being cut apart with the books.
Sold off.
Miniatures, calendars, the whole bit.
From your collection.

Pardon me?

In the Boston area?

It was at the same time?

About three years ago.

But I have my facts, I mean, I have my notes.

A BU guy?
Yeah.
No, this guy was from Getty Museum.
Oh.
Because I was about ready to drop a name on them.
And I said, my problem is you gauge in these million-dollar sales or they'll sell a lot of eight or nine, ten artifacts in return for X number of dollars.

The big one.

Well, that's an impermanence of books.
Because...
I'm writing about the destruction of books in this next book.
We've got a guy in the art history department.
I love something like this.
This is good stuff.

In terms of what you lose, in terms of being able to know about both the book... This is great English.

and everything surrounding it and you'd be an interesting person to talk with and he's been interested in in seeing if you could do a census of leaves and begin to put books back together virtually so that you're at least you could digitally put them put them back together the problem with that and i've tried to put leaves books back together the problem with that is they are sold on the open market
to people who have just enough money to buy them and not enough money to understand what they have.
And so they're hanging in homes.
And I told you the story of the medieval wills.
Well, there's no question, John.
I mean, I'm not going to argue with you about it.
Oh, no, no, I'm not, my friend.
I'm just telling you.
The dispersal, it's a crime.
It is a crime.
His idea is wonderful.
You know, what...
Oh, this is Eric Gables.
He teaches art history here at Oregon.
I-N-G-L-E-S?
I-N-G-L-I-S.
I-N-G-L-I-S.
But I can get you in time.
Just so I know.
No, you're right.
And that's a wonderful thing.
And if we could do it.
It's just that they have made sure that a number of these leads go out into, for lack of another term, hands of people who have no idea what they are.
Remember the story of the medieval wills?
I told you the story of the medieval wills that were bound, and the guy sewed them off as chapter rules, and one of my interns translated them as wills.
It was a whole book of medieval wills.
They were hawked off, broken, sewed off.

The way I got him back, Nick, the guy who broke this book of medieval wills, he took out the miniature, which was a monastic order, he sold it to a private collector, and I know who it was, and then he cut the book off, and he put on him rules of the chapter.
He didn't even read it.
I mean, he can't read it.

One of my interns at the College of Worcester, summer project, had 12 of these hot shot Latin young men, great young men, calls me one night, he says, Professor Lawrence, and I'm not a professor, but he called me a
He said, I'm sure these are chapter rules.
And I go, Jason, what are they?
They're wills.
I said, makes sense.
So we did a research.
He did a paper on it, which I'll supply to you.
And a copy of the paper.
And it turns out this was a bound copy, bound book of wills.
And one of the wills we have says by the scribe,
And a copy of this shall be placed in the monastery's library.
So that's why they were there.
Because the monastery served as a probate court everywhere.
The guy had broken a book of wills.
Now he was selling these for $75 a lease.
And I bought every one I could find.
So I called him up and said, do you know what you took apart?
He goes, no, why?
You took apart a book of medieval wills.
And I think they would have sold for $2,000 each.
Now you do the math.
See, that's where you get out of it.
And he came back and later called me.
So he split the wills apart.
Oh, he split the whole book apart.
And he sold them off as rules of the chapter.
So the people bought these for $75 each.
But in effect, there were intact wills that were split apart in the whole process?
Yeah, where they were intact wills.
Not only were the wills split from the book, the wills were split apart.
That's what I'm saying.
The wills themselves were split.
So that if you don't have the full content of an individual will... See, none of these people can read the language.
No, and he hawked it off.
And I called him up, and I said, these would have went for two grand each.
And that really got him.
I mean, that depressed him for days.
But what I started to say about the Marguerite de Bacobala Tiffano, when the exhibition opens, I'm going to tell the story of her book.
And, you know, before then, hopefully I can tell the story to you.
But it will be in the exhibition, because the scholars want to know.
So I dropped the name to one of these guys.
I said, I'm going to have to start naming names, folks.
And he looked at me and he said, you're not.
I said, I got to.
I said, I can't stand up in front of a group of scholars and dance around.
And every one of these people,

is up to here in their arms in one way or the other courageous philip courageous out in oregon advertises in his book i do not break books no he doesn't he stands while the guy does it i mean he buys it from a book breaker no he doesn't do it himself but he goes in and he buys the leaves from a book book he really specializes in
entire books.
He's more, he's not a real big medieval manuscript dealer.
He's got a good reputation, actually.
He does have one.
But they have to make a living, Nick.
That's how they do this.
John, do you object to this on aesthetic grounds that you have a book that's moral grounds?
On moral grounds?
In terms of every kind of ground you can think of.
Well, first of all, I object to a beautiful intact book being taken apart for any reason.
And I object to
when the objective of taking a part has nothing to do with scholarship and what I call the democratization of history.
The democratization of history is this, like the book of hours I have, you can only enjoy two folios at once.
If you can, if individual collectors out there have a manuscript lead, they become interested in medieval history, renaissance history, writing books,
A lot of these people that I do buy leaves that come leave, take very great care of them.
They're archived rights.
They love them.
They're family heirlooms.
They document them.
I write valuations and descriptions.
So there's that.
But when you're talking a healthy book of hours, a pristine book of hours that's cut apart to accomplish that, that's wrong.
If you have a damaged book that was taken apart, part of it in the 19th century, 18th century, damaged, that's another story.
I've got a book of hours.
that has about 100 leaves in it.
The calendars are gone.
The miniatures are gone.
It was re-sewn in the 60s very badly to put it in a new binding upside down.
I haven't taken that book apart.
I have it.
You know, it's a matter of degree.
There's no difference between what he's talking about and what Baker's talking about with those newspapers coming from the British Library that he chopped up for birthday parties.
With Baker's style, that's a whole other thing.
It's really true that when you film that you lose, with certain thinkers, you lose
an ability to know and understand what that artifact is reflecting.
So with the newspapers, all of those color illustrations, those incredible color illustrations in the early 20th century newspapers, that's just all lost.
I tell a story in the book.
Here, the interesting thing from what Eric was telling me is that when a book is broken like that,

what you lose in terms of your ability to then both understand the book but understand the period and understand the whole culture that it's coming from because you there are certain things that just don't make sense unless you have the whole thing the paratextual elements of the book the whole book as artifact matters it creates something that's easier with synergy you know when i have my collection i still have the prices on it it's where some of these books
people, and I like to call book people, book breakers, will take a leaf and then cut the leaf into squares.
and hawk them off at $25 a square.
Calligraphy shows.
Here is a 12th century cistercen leaf.
Those things retail for like $2,000, but it's fine cistercen script, fine cistercen vellum on parchment.
